headline: A Thought on Economics for Obama
summary: Would the president suggest that we return to the farming methods of the year 1900 to help ease the unemployment problem?

headline: The 'Perfect' Office
summary: Four design firms were challenged to configure a 15-foot by 15-foot space for a hypothetical mid-level executive.

headline: Mixed Bag for CD Yields
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mixed in the latest week.

headline: More Bidders For Sterling Hospitals
summary: Kolkata-based Emami Group and U.S.-based Fidelity International are among a growing list of suitors for private-equity firm Actis Advisors' 80% stake in Sterling Hospitals.

headline: U.S. to Tackle Curbs to India Investments
summary: The U.S. will tackle trade barriers to investment in India during high-level talks in Washington next week, seeking to tap opportunities in one of the fastest-growing economies in the world, a senior U.S. Treasury official said.

headline: Apple May Face Antitrust Probe in India
summary: India's antitrust agency has received a complaint against Apple requesting that the body look into whether the U.S. smartphone maker violated local competition laws when selling its popular iPhone 4 smartphone.

headline: AstraZeneca's Too-Concentrated Solution
summary: Most big pharma companies nowadays are looking to diversify. Not AstraZeneca, which believes in sticking to its knitting.

headline: House Bill Eases Offshore-Drilling Rules
summary: The House voted to streamline the issuance of clean-air permits for offshore oil-drilling projects, representing another attempt by Republicans to pressure the Obama administration into speeding up domestic oil production.

headline: Jefferies Expands Team in Asia
summary: Jefferies Group has hired four bankers for its equity business in India and Singapore as part of its global expansion plans.

headline: India to Form Panel to Oversee Air India Turnaround
summary: The Indian government will form a new panel of officials to oversee the turnaround plan for loss-making national carrier Air India, the country's aviation minister has said.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Thursday, June 23, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Lawmakers Back Covered Bonds
summary: A U.S. House of Representatives panel signed off on a bipartisan bill aimed at encouraging a robust market for covered bonds, a type of mortgage-backed security commonly issued in Europe.

headline: Rove: Why Obama Is Likely to Lose in 2012
summary: Even a small drop in the share of black voters would wipe out his winning margin in North Carolina.

headline: Google, Citigroup Invest More in Wind Farm
summary: Google and Citigroup said they will each invest an additional $102 million in a California wind farm, bolstering a facility they say will be the nation's largest wind-energy provider by the end of this year.

headline: CIT Says Tyco's Tax Claims 'Undermine' Reorganization
summary: CIT Group emerged from the financial crisis with the help of a federal bailout and a quick trip through bankruptcy court, but that rescue could be undermined if the commercial lender's former owner, Tyco International, succeeds in laying claim to nearly $800 million in tax benefits.

headline: Online Medical Services Provider Raises Money
summary: Angels Health, an online medical services company founded by Debraj Shome and Arbinder Singal, has received its first funding from the private equity unit of India's largest mortgage lender.

headline: Microfinance Firm Gets Fresh Round of Funding
summary: In what could be pegged as a revival of investor interest in firms offering credit to the poor, micro-lender Janalakshmi Financial Services has raised $14.67 million in its third round of funding from private equity firms.

headline: India Inc. Turns More to Private Equity: Study
summary: Private equity investments in India's corporate sector has outstripped the contribution India Inc. received from public equity over the past six years, a report said.

headline: Report Warns on San Andreas Quake
summary: More than 430,000 businesses would be severely impacted by a major earthquake in southern California, according to a federal report released this week.

headline: Faster Review of Diabetes Technology Urged
summary: Congress continued to press the FDA to speed its review of an artificial pancreas, a diabetes technology that supporters say has the potential to ease daily patient management of the disease.

headline: Diamond Monitor Grapples With Zimbabwe Decision
summary: Members of the Kimberley Process are scrambling to bridge differences over Zimbabwe's exports from a controversial diamond field, in a bid to stave off the collapse of the global diamond-monitoring group.

headline: Outlook Grows Bleak on Main Street
summary: Small businesses are putting the brakes on hiring and capital-spending plans, amid concerns that the U.S. economy is still in a recession, new survey data show.

headline: Bill Aims to End Marijuana Prohibition
summary: The House bill is designed to limit the federal government's role in enforcing marijuana laws.

headline: Morgan Keegan Settlement Expected
summary: Regulators are expected to announce a settlement totaling roughly $200 million with Morgan Keegan to resolve civil fraud charges brought by the SEC over troubled bond funds.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Columnist Mary Ann Milbourn on the heavy flow of jobs out of California and into Utah.

headline: Brazil Mulls Support for Carstens IMF Bid
summary: Brazil may throw its support behind Mexico's central bank chief Agustín Carstens in his bid to become the next head of the International Monetary Fund, according to Brazil's representative at the IMF.

headline: Options Bulls Jump Into L-3
summary: Interest in the defense contractor increased after a report that Relational Investors acquired a 6% stake in the company and is pushing to break up the firm.

headline: HHS Delays Rules on Consumer Appeals
summary: The Obama administration delayed a piece of the health overhaul designed to help consumers appeal insurance-claim denials.

headline: Debt-Ceiling Standoff Restricts Muni-Market 'Slugs'
summary: With Congress and the White House playing a game of political chicken over raising the debt ceiling, state and local governments have been forced to find alternatives to a source of federal financing that backs a common type of muni bond.

headline: Dynegy Taps Independent Director Flexon as CEO
summary: Dynegy named current independent director Robert Flexon as chief executive Wednesday, the latest change at the top of the power generator after a protracted fight for its control.

headline: Bahrain Sentences 8 Activists to Life
summary: A Bahrain military court sentenced eight high-profile political activists to life in prison for plotting to overthrow the government, the latest in a series of harsh jail terms for those that took part in demonstrations this year.

headline: Taiwan Regulator Rejects KKR Buyout of Yageo
summary: Taiwan's financial regulator rejected the proposed $1.6 billion cash offer for Taiwan's Yageo from the founder of the electronics components company and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Former Treasury Secretary Signs Book Deal
summary: Henry Paulson has signed a deal to write a book about U.S.-China economic relations, drawing on his experience as Treasury secretary and CEO of Goldman Sachs.

headline: U.K. Charges Man in Cybercrime Case
summary: British prosecutors charged a 19-year-old man with cybercrime offenses in connection with an investigation into an international hacking group.

headline: Photos of the Day: June 22
summary: In today's pictures, Philadelphia's pools open for business, deadly protests rattle an Indian city, a Chinese university hosts a graduation ceremony, and more.

headline: Money Exits Mutual Funds
summary: Long-term mutual funds had estimated outflows of $4.5 billion in the latest week, as investors pulled more money from U.S. and foreign equity funds, according to the Investment Company Institute.

headline: DJIA's Winning Streak Ends
summary: U.S. stocks snapped a four-day winning streak, stumbling in late trading after the Federal Reserve issued a cautious economic outlook just days before it ends its asset-buying program.

headline: SEC Slaps Some Strictures on Venture-Capital Funds
summary: Venture-capital managers will gain a broad exemption from registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission but may be subject to regulatory examinations.

headline: NRG, ProLogis Initiate Rooftop Solar Project
summary: NRG Energy is joining with warehouse operator ProLogis to install rooftop solar panels in 28 states.

headline: Thornburg Trustee Targets BofA Over Countrywide Loans
summary: The court-appointed trustee overseeing the liquidation of Thornburg Mortgage is taking aim at what he calls BofA's "elaborate corporate shell game" to move the valuable assets of its Countrywide mortgage lending subsidiary into the bank.

headline: RWE Sues Against Nuclear Tax
summary: Utility RWE said it has filed litigation against the German nuclear fuel tax, marking what is expected to be the kickoff of a series of lawsuits against the levy and the government's recent atomic energy policy shift.

headline: Corn, Wheat Slide
summary: Selling by speculative investors sparked a slide in grains prices, with corn futures hitting the daily limit on losses and wheat falling more than 5%.

headline: Mutual Fund Embraces the Euro
summary: Axel Merk, who oversees about $700 million in currency strategies, expects the dollar to keep weakening for some time, and not by accident. And so he said positioned his Merk Hard Currency Fund to profit from the U.S. dollar's decline, favoring the euro, Swedish krona, Australian dollar and Canadian dollar.

headline: Christie's Chief Heads to Qatar
summary: In the latest reshuffling at the world's largest auction house, Edward Dolman, Christie's International PLC's chairman, is leaving to be an executive director at the Qatar Museums Authority.

headline: Oil Settles Above $95 a Barrel
summary: Oil futures ended higher as traders looked past the Federal Reserve's downbeat assessment of the U.S. economy and focused on a bigger-than-expected decline in U.S. oil inventories.

headline: Small Margin of Error for Europe's Retailers
summary: The squeeze on discretionary consumer spending across Europe is set to worsen, and that will keep a lid on shares of the region's retailers.

headline: Syrian Official Slams Sanctions
summary: Syria's foreign minister said the country wouldn't bow to external pressure to accelerate reforms and reinforced the regime's offer of a "national dialogue" as the only way out of the conflict between President Bashar al-Assad's regime and protesters.

headline: SEC Blocks Nasdaq Proposal for 'Stockpiler' Listings
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission blocked an effort by Nasdaq OMX Group to list shares in companies that stockpile commodities, warning that such stocks would be susceptible to manipulation.

summary: Gold futures settled near a two-month high after the Federal Open Market Committee left U.S. monetary policy unchanged.

headline: In Chile, an IPO Boomlet Percolates

summary: Rolls-Royce plans to offer Boeing the same new jet-engine technology it recently pledged to rival Airbus for its planned A350 aircraft.

summary: China's Gome Electrical said it filed suit against its former chairman, saying he gave "false and misleading" information about the retailer in an interview to a Chinese publication.

headline: Judge Reluctantly Approves Borders' Quick-Sale Schedule
summary: A judge on Wednesday gave Borders Group Inc. the go-ahead on an aggressive schedule that the bookseller hopes will result in a bidder for its remaining assets emerging by July 1. The bookseller is also hoping for a transaction closing by the end of July, as Borders looks to keep at least some of its remaining locations in business.

headline: ANA: Dreamliner Orders on Track
summary: All Nippon Airways said it is on track to take first delivery of the long-delayed Boeing 787 Dreamliner in August or September.

headline: MUFG Credit-Card Unit Sees Post-Quake Business
summary: The March 11 earthquake and tsunami has created an unexpected opportunity for Mitsubishi UFJ Nicos and other Japanese credit-card issuers.

headline: New CEO Pledges to Streamline Mizuho
summary: New Mizuho CEO Yasuhiro Sato gave a blunt assessment of the bank's recent problems, saying its bloated management structure hindered corporate governance and was one of several factors prolonging a computer-system failure.

headline: China to Speed Housing Bonds
summary: In an apparent bid to ease a severe funding shortage, China's top economic-planning agency will make it easier for local governments to issue bonds to finance public-housing construction, even as Beijing seeks to crack down on wayward local borrowing.

headline: Photos of the Day: June 21
summary: In today's pictures, a solstice fan seeks height at Stonehenge, a survivor of a deadly plane crash in Russia is taken to a hospital, a line judge keeps his eye on the ball at Wimbledon, and more.

headline: Tech IPOs Take Low-Float Tack. A High-Risk Move?
summary: For highflying technology companies, a "low float" strategy is becoming a common theme, but it has also fueled some observers' concerns of another tech-stock bubble.

headline: Drafting Rubio
summary: The Republican nomination for president is completely up for grabs, but there's a lot of agreement on who the vice presidential pick should be: freshman senator Marco Rubio.

headline: Europe's Markets Fall
summary: European stocks fell as investors looked beyond a confidence-vote victory by Greece's government to fresh evidence that the European consumer environment is showing signs of extreme stress.

headline: BP Seeks to Build 300 Gas Wells in Oman
summary: U.K. energy giant BP aims to develop 300 natural-gas wells in Oman in what would be one of the company's largest global projects, its CEO said.

headline: Hyundai Heavy Sees Rise in Ship Orders
summary: Korea's Hyundai Heavy forecast that ship orders will nearly double this year, though demand in the second half is unlikely to match that of the first.

summary: India's ambitious Food Security Bill that promises cheap grains to millions of poor people will add $24.55 billion to the government's annual subsidy bill.

summary: India's capital markets watchdog said it is looking to regulate distributors of mutual funds even as it acknowledged the need to give them incentives to boost falling sales.

headline: Ban on Kurdish Lawmaker Sparks Protests
summary: A decision to bar an elected Kurdish candidate from Turkey's parliament triggered protests and warnings of "chaos" from a top Kurdish politician.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Australia Imposes Sanctions Against Syria
summary: Australia is imposing financial sanctions against Syria amid growing international condemnation of the deadly crackdown on protesters by President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: U.S. to Discourage Food Export Bans
summary: The U.S. will push for more transparent food production and open markets to reduce food price volatility at Thursday's meeting of big economy agricultural ministers, U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack said.

headline: Argentine President to Seek Re-Election
summary: Argentina's President Cristina Fernández said Tuesday she will seek another four-year term in October's presidential election, ending months of speculation about her plans.

headline: France Discusses Greek Debt With Banks
summary: The French government met with the country's banks to discuss a voluntary rollover of Greece's sovereign debt, French officials said, as the country moved to involve the private sector in the next Greek financial support package.

summary: Japanese stocks rose sharply on optimism that Greece can push through austerity measures and avoid defaulting on its debt, though interest-rate worries dragged back bourses in Hong Kong and China.

headline: Philips Warns on Profit

summary: Consumers in the 17 nations that use the euro became slightly less confident about their prospects in June, while factory orders across the currency area rose less than expected in April.

headline: Nissan Nears Normal Output

headline: Geithner: Banks Set to Draw From Small-Business Fund
summary: Banks have requested $11.6 billion from the administration's signature small-business lending program, U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner says, about one-third of what's available.

headline: Toxic Material at Japan Plant Raises Risks
summary: Excessive levels of highly toxic strontium have been detected in seawater and groundwater at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex, the plant operator said, a development that suggests an increased risk of radioactive contamination further entering the food chain.

headline: Eni Faces Bribery Investigation
summary: Italian oil giant Eni and its Saipem unit are under investigation into alleged bribery related to engineering contracts in Kuwait and Iraq, the companies said.

headline: Yahoo, Alibaba, Softbank Continue Talks
summary: Yahoo, Alibaba Group and Softbank said they "continue to be engaged in constructive negotiations" on Alipay, a Chinese online payment service.

headline: Novartis Seen Gaining as Merck Scraps MS Drug

headline: India Shares End Flat on Weak Monsoon Forecast
summary: Indian shares closed flat after a light, choppy session, underperforming most other Asian markets as the weather department's forecast of a below-normal monsoon stoked fears of a possible slowdown in economic growth.

headline: UAE Stock Market Seen Closer to MSCI Upgrade
summary: Investors see the United Arab Emirates as far closer to clinching promotion to the rank of "emerging market" from MSCI than its Persian Gulf neighbor Qatar, a day after the index compiler outlined its concerns about upgrading both countries and delayed a decision by six months.

headline: H&M Feels Squeeze on Margins

headline: Japan's DPJ to Extend Parliament
summary: Japan's ruling party decided to extend the current parliamentary session by 70 days to ensure the passage of key legislation needed to finance post-quake reconstruction, but an entrenched lack of support from opposition parties suggests the country's political paralysis is likely to continue.

headline: Nine Dragons Plans Bond Redemption
summary: Nien Dragons plans to redeem nearly $46 million in outstanding bonds a week after Standard & Poor's withdrew its rating on the company, which led to sudden scrutiny of the paperboard maker and a swift defense from management.

headline: India Grain Export Prospects Fade
summary: The prospects of India exporting wheat and rice have virtually disappeared, industry officials said following a forecast that rains in the June-September monsoon season will be below normal.

headline: Japan's Short-Term Yields Fall
summary: Yields on short-term Japanese government debt fell after an auction of treasury discount bills went well, the latest sign that the country's financial institutions remain flush with cash, much of which has been flowing into low-risk assets.

headline: New Look in Hamburg

headline: Zuari Ups Stake in Nagarjuna Fertilizers
summary: In a little over a year, Zuari Industries -- one of India's biggest fertilizer companies -- has built a 6.66% stake in rival Nagarjuna Fertilizers and Chemicals.

headline: Serena Fails to Ward Off Tears
summary: There is something ridiculously epic about the return to Wimbledon of Serena Williams. Her life is the sort of story that film-makers would never dare to dream up and when the reigning champion sobbed after her victory on Centre Court, you could be forgiven for pinching yourself.

headline: Nickel Is No Guide to Base-Metal Prices
summary: Changes in nickel prices are often seen as offering clues about the outlook for other base metals, but analyst say nickel's nearly 26% slide since February offers no reason to worry about the overall market.

headline: Electrical Retail in U.K. Faces Shake Up
summary: The U.K. electrical retail sector is facing a major shake-up in the next few months as two retail chains mired in a prolonged slump in consumer-electricals sales consider their high street futures.

headline: AstraZeneca Sells Dental Unit
summary: AstraZeneca said it has agreed to sell Astra Tech to Dentsply International for $1.8 billion, after a sale process that attracted strong interest from private-equity firms and strategic buyers.

headline: Cathay Pacific Plans Economy-Class Overhaul
summary: Cathay Pacific plans to offer new economy class seats on its aircraft in the third quarter at the earliest, in the Hong Kong-based carrier's latest effort to compete with other top airline brands.

headline: India's IPOs in a Lull
summary: This year, only about a dozen Indian companies have gone through with an initial public offering to raise a total of $600 million. While more companies are expected to go public in the coming months, it's unlikely that the total will surpass last year's $8.56 billion raised by listing 66 companies.

headline: U.K. Advances Energy Overhaul
summary: U.K. energy regulator Ofgem said it will press ahead with its plans for a "radical overhaul" of the retail gas and electricity market.

headline: Coal India to Invest $223.3 Million in Mutual Funds
summary: Coal India, which has cash reserves of about $9.6 billion, plans to invest up to $223.3 million in mutual funds this year as part of a new strategy to get better returns on its surplus cash.

headline: Vote Gives Berlusconi Policy Nod
summary: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi warned that bond markets would punish the country if his government fell, leading to massive cuts to health care and other public services.

headline: Norilsk Gets a New Chairman
summary: The battle for the control in the world's largest nickel miner, Norilsk Nickel, intensified as a representative of Russian billionaire Vladimir Potanin was elected chairman of the board.

headline: India's Folk Instruments

headline: Norwegian Airline in $1.2 Billion Boeing Order
summary: Low-fare carrier Norwegian Air Shuttle announced an order for 15 new Boeing Co. 737-800 jets and finalized a previous order for three 787 Dreamliner wide-bodies.

headline: TCS Assures Investors of Strong Demand
summary: Tata Consultancy Services sought to allay investors' concerns, saying demand for outsourcing services remains strong despite economic weakness in the largest outsourcing markets of the U.S. and Europe.

headline: State-Run National Building Picks IPO Managers
summary: The Indian federal government has selected Enam Securities and IDBI Capital to manage its planned sale of a 10% stake in National Building Construction Corp. through an initial public offering.

headline: Russian Airline to Order 40 Boeing Jets
summary: Russian carrier UTair Aviation is slated to announce an order for 40 Boeing 737 jets, according to people familiar with the details.

headline: Lupin Expects Better Operating Margin in Two Years
summary: Lupin may find it tough to improve its operating margin this fiscal year through March, but the Indian generic drug maker's profitability is expected to jump in a couple of years, helped mainly by the launch of several lucrative products in the U.S. and lower research costs.

headline: Elpida Unveils Thinner Mobile Chip
summary: Elpida Memory said it has developed a memory chip package that is 20% thinner than similar packages on the market, a breakthrough it says will help make mobile gadgets thinner while maintaining memory capacity.

headline: Trade Data Suggest Slowdown
summary: World trade volumes fell in April for the first time since September 2010, a fresh indication that the global economy is slowing.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: North Korean soldiers film the South side from a border village, Indian Sikh pilgrims board a train for Pakistan, workers install the world's fastest supercomputer in Japan, and more.

headline: Toyota to Launch Etios Liva in India
summary: Toyota Motor's India unit said it will introduce its Etios Liva small car on June 27.

headline: Greek Financier Pays $29 Million for a Picasso
summary: A Greek financier based in London paid Christie's $29.1 million on Tuesday for a Pablo Picasso painting that was once caught up in a daring World War II-era rescue.

headline: UTAC Delays Singapore IPO
summary: United Test Assembly Center delayed its planned initial public offering in Singapore, indicating that investors' risk appetite remains weak due to the poor global economic outlook.

headline: SAP Ventures to Add to India Portfolio
summary: After nearly three years, SAP Ventures, the investment arm of German software firm SAP invested in another Indian firm. Jai Das, a managing director at SAP Ventures, said the country is among the fund's top three destinations.

headline: Carrefour Faces Rowdy Protesters
summary: Carrefour CEO Lars Olofsson will also become chairman, and Carrefour shareholders approved the spinoff of the struggling retailer's Dia discount unit at a raucous meeting.

headline: At the 'Bad Teacher' Premiere, and Later
summary: "Bad Teacher," a new relatively-low budget comedy that opens Friday, starring the big-budget cast of Cameron Diaz, Justin Timberlake and Jason Segal, had a splashy premiere at the Ziegfeld.

headline: Saudi Suggests 'Squeezing' Iran
summary: A leading member of Saudi Arabia's royal family warned that Riyadh could seek to supplant Iran's oil exports if the country doesn't constrain its nuclear program, a move that could hobble Tehran's finances.

headline: Developer Buys Site of Failed Trump Tower
summary: A partnership led by Florida real-estate developer Robert Owens paid $5 million for the site of the failed Trump Tower Tampa condo project and an adjacent six-story office building.

headline: A Founding Father Who Frolicked
summary: Mr. Hamilton lost his public influence when he was caught in problems similar to those of a far more recent, like-thinking president, Bill Clinton.

headline: Soft-Spoken Huntsman Enters GOP Race
summary: Former Utah Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr. launched his White House bid, with a promise of civility in his quest for the presidency.

headline: New York Hotels Fetch Luxury Price
summary: Pebblebrook Hotel Trust is purchasing a 49% share in six Manhattan boutique hotels for $152 million in the latest sign of the rising heat of New York's hotel market.

headline: Obama to Unveil Troop-Drawdown Plan
summary: Obama will announce the first steps in a gradual plan to extract the U.S. from the Afghanistan war.

headline: UBS Aids Probe of Rate Collusion
summary: Swiss bank UBS is aiding investigators trying to determine whether major banks colluded to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, a measure of bank borrowing costs, before and during the financial crisis.

headline: ONGC May Launch Share Sale by Mid-July
summary: India's Oil and Natural Gas Corp.'s follow-on-share sale is likely to be by mid-July as the government has appointed new independent directors to meet regulatory listing rules.

headline: SEC Weighs Curbs on Backdoor Stock Listing
summary: SEC Chairman Mary Schapiro said the agency is considering several options to address its concerns about companies that use legal but backdoor methods to list shares of their stocks in North America.

summary: In the latest of a string of high-level departures to hit Swiss banking giant UBS, its head of global mergers and acquisitions has defected to become a partner at New York-based boutique Moelis & Co.

headline: All's Well at Public Theater Gala
summary: Young and anointed, the alumni of recent Shakespeare in the Park productions gathered in little eddies along the edges of the Public Theater's gala dinner on Monday night in Central Park before a performance of "All's Well That Ends Well."

summary: Cutting off funds is not a bill of attainder.

summary: Police seized $36 million in assets from Chinese-owned companies in Italy's textile-making areas near Florence, in an antifraud crackdown on Chinese producers.

summary: The wisest military course also pays political dividends.

summary: The complete eradication of smallpox is a remarkable success story for modern medicine and public health. Betsy McKay reviews "House on Fire."

headline: PetroChina Burns Gas Producers
summary: PetroChina just pulled off a neat trick: boosting the natural-gas market while thwarting the exploration-and-production sector.

headline: B&N Digital Plan Pays Off, But Its Cost Widens Loss
summary: Barnes & Noble saw its digital strategy pay off in its fiscal fourth quarter with healthy gains on the e-book and e-reader front, but investments in that business took a toll on the bottom line.

summary: More than 200 Thai restaurants in New York City offer startlingly similar menus. So it can be disorienting to order at Zabb Elee, a new East Village Thai restaurant that offers a departure from dishes found at many of them.

headline: Momentum Gone in Design Services
summary: The Architecture Billings Index fell again last month, reflecting a continued decline in demand for design services.

headline: Gore-Tex Faces Antitrust Probes
summary: The maker of Gore-Tex, a waterproof material used in sportswear, is the target of antitrust investigations in the U.S. and Europe.

headline: Gertrude Whitney's Gambit
summary: Part of it was taste, part of it was being ahead of trends. A look at the earliest acquisitions in the Whitney Museum's collection.
